metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: AngularJS Events
AngularJS has its own HTML events directives.
content.html: AngularJS has its own HTML events directives.

content.text: AngularJS Events
You can add AngularJS event listeners to your HTML elements by using one or more of these directives:
content.html: You can add AngularJS event listeners to your HTML elements by using one or more of these directives:

content.text: The event directives allows us to run AngularJS functions at certain user events.
content.html: The event directives allows us to run AngularJS functions at certain user events.

content.text: An AngularJS event will not overwrite an HTML event, both events will be executed.
content.html: An AngularJS event will not overwrite an HTML event, both events will be executed.

content.text: Mouse Events
Mouse events occur when the cursor moves over an element, in this order:
content.html: Mouse events occur when the cursor moves over an element, in this order:

content.text: Or when a mouse button is clicked on an element, in this order:
content.html: Or when a mouse button is clicked on an element, in this order:

content.text: You can add mouse events on any HTML element.
content.html: You can add mouse events on any HTML element.

content.code:
Mouse over me!

{{ count }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="count = count + 1">Mouse over me!</h1>

<h2>{{ count }}</h2>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.count = 0;
});
</script>

content.text: The ng-click Directive
The ng-click directive defines AngularJS code that will be executed when the element is being clicked.
content.html: The ng-click directive defines AngularJS code that will be executed when the element is being clicked.

content.code: {{ count }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<button ng-click="count = count + 1">Click me!</button>

<p>{{ count }}</p>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.count = 0;
});
</script>

content.text: You can also refer to a function:
content.html: You can also refer to a function:

content.code: {{ count }}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<button ng-click="myFunction()">Click me!</button>

<p>{{ count }}</p>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.count = 0;
  $scope.myFunction = function() {
    $scope.count++;
  }
});
</script>

content.text: Toggle, True/False
If you want to show a section of HTML code when a button is clicked, and hide when the button is clicked again, like a dropdown menu, make the button behave like a toggle switch:
content.html: If you want to show a section of HTML code when a button is clicked, and hide when the button is clicked again, like a dropdown menu, make the button behave like a toggle switch:

content.text: Click Me
Menu:

content.code:
Menu:

Pizza
 
Pasta
  
Pesce
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<button ng-click="myFunc()">Click Me!</button>

<div ng-show="showMe">
  <h1>Menu:</h1>
  <div>Pizza</div>
  <div>Pasta</div>
  <div>Pesce</div>
</div>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.showMe = false;
  $scope.myFunc = function() {
    $scope.showMe = !$scope.showMe;
  }
});
</script>

content.text: The showMe variable starts out as the Boolean value false .
content.html: The showMe variable starts out as the Boolean value false.

content.text: The myFunc function sets the showMe variable to the opposite of what it is, by using the ! (not) operator.
content.html: The myFunc function sets the showMe variable to the opposite of what it is, by using the ! (not) operator.

content.text: $event Object
You can pass the $event object as an argument when calling the function.
content.html: You can pass the $event object as an argument when calling the function.

content.text: The $event object contains the browser's event object:
content.html: The $event object contains the browser's event object:

content.code:
Mouse Over Me!

Coordinates: {{x + ', ' + y}}
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="myFunc($event)">Mouse Over Me!</h1>

<p>Coordinates: {{x + ', ' + y}}</p>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.myFunc = function(myE) {
    $scope.x = myE.clientX;
    $scope.y = myE.clientY;
  }
});
</script>
